Award.AwardTitle: The internal structure of deposits emplaced under upper plane bed / sheet flow transport conditions: Laboratory experiments and numerical modeling
Award.AbstractNarration:
The internal structure of deposits emplaced under upper plane bed/sheet flow transport conditions: Laboratory experiments and numerical modeling
Enrica Viparelli, EAR-1250641, University of South Carolina
ABSTRACT
Rock deposits emplaced by storms and turbidity currents can be characterized by a lower erosional boundary underlying a massive unit followed in ascending order by a parallel laminated unit and a cross laminated unit. Such deposits are interpreted to be emplaced by waning energy flows. Massive units are macroscopically structureless, i.e. there is not a visible organization of sediment particles within the deposit. In the laminated units, sediment particles of different size are deposited with visible patterns.
The main objective of this research is to investigate and model flow and sediment transport conditions that are responsible for the emplacement of massive and parallel laminated units. Laboratory and field studies demonstrate that parallel laminated units are emplaced under sediment transport conditions known as upper plane bed regime. These conditions are characterized by i) a moving bedload layer one or two grain diameters thick, and ii) downstream migrating low amplitude bedforms. As the parallel laminated unit is deposited under upper plane bed regime, the basal unit has to be emplaced under more intense transport conditions. The central hypotheses of the proposed research are that i) those intense transport conditions correspond to sheet flow, which is a mode of bedload transport characterized by a bedload layer 10-100s grain diameters thick, ii) the sheet flow layer can suppress the formation of parallel laminations, and iii) this suppression results in a tendency to homogenize the grain fabric of the emplaced deposit under conditions of continued deposition. It must be acknowledged that sheet flow is not the only mechanism that produces massive deposits, but the conditions for it to operate can be commonly met at field scale.
Based on the results of preliminary laboratory experiments, an experimental and numerical program is proposed to characterize the deposition of massive versus parallel laminated deposits. Open channel, i.e. river-like, laboratory experiments will be performed to build a deposit under upper regime plane bed and sheet flow transport conditions. The choice of this experimental setting is dictated by the need to induce sediment deposition in the sheet flow regime at laboratory scale. However, the experiments will be specifically designed to model intense and net-depositional subaqueous flows. The numerical program is centered on the development of a model that is able to reproduce the grain fabric of the deposits emplaced under upper plane bed and sheet flow transport conditions. The model will be validated against the experimental results. The results of the laboratory and numerical work will provide the necessary information to i) characterize the mechanics of upper plane bed and sheet flow transport regimes in general, and ii) relate the grain fabric of the deposit to the characteristics of the flow and the sediment transport. They are thus expected to have a transformative impact on the communities studying subaqueous sedimentary processes, coastal and deep-water engineering.
One graduate student will take the lead in the performance of the experimental and numerical work to pursue his PhD research. He will also be responsible for the organization of the laboratory and numerical data and for their timely dissemination through the CDSMS and the NCED repositories. Four undergraduate students will be hired in three years to prepare them for graduate studies via undergraduate research projects that will be directly supervised by the PI.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Deposits formed by coastal storms and turbidity currents, i.e. flows that transport a large amount of sediment on the bottom of the ocean or lakes, provide information on the characteristics of past extreme events and can contain hydrocarbon reservoirs.  These deposits are generally characterized by a lower erosional surface followed in ascending order by a sandy deposit and a muddy deposit.  In general, the sandy deposit can be divided in three parts, 1) a basal unit in which the sand grains do not seem to be organized in any particular pattern (massive unit), 2) an intermediate unit in which the sand grains are organized in long, continuous and nearly horizontal thin layers (parallel laminated), and 3) a top layer in which the sand grains are organized in strongly inclined laminae.  One example of a massive and a parallel laminated unit is presented in Figure 1. 

 

Previous studies demonstrated that the two laminated units are formed in presence of sediment waves somewhat similar to those that can be observed on the bottom of a river or on a sandy beach.  The mechanisms for the formation of the massive units are less clear.  They are thought to form when a very strong current transports the sand in suspension and then deposits it very rapidly.  This research project was built on the hypothesis that suspended sediment transport and rapid deposition were not necessary for the formation of a massive unit.  In other words, the hypothesis of this project was that a strong current was able to move sand in a near bed layer (sheet flow layer) when sediment waves were absent and sediment deposition from this near bed layer resulted in the formation of the sandy massive units.

 

To test this hypothesis we performed laboratory experiments in the Hydraulics Laboratory of the Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering at the University of South Carolina that resulted in the formation of parallel laminated and massive deposits.  In particular, the experiments showed that 1) the massive units were deposited by stronger currents than the parallel laminated units, and 2) in the experiments with the deposition of massive units sediment waves did not form and the sand was transported in a sheet flow layer. Examples of parallel laminated and massive units obtained in the experiments respectively are in Figures 2 and 3.  

The experiments, which were performed with unidirectional open channel flow, also provided information for the characterization of the flow and of the sediment transport processes that may occur during floods and other extreme events.  In particular, the experiments demonstrated that when sediment waves are present, they are responsible for the formation of additional resistances to the flow.  Thus, in the calculation of the water levels during extreme events the prediction of the bed configuration (plane or with sediment waves) is important to safely determine the flood stage for a given river discharge.  Previous studies suggested that during extreme events the sediment waves not always had a significant impact on the flow resistances.

 

INTELLECTUAL MERIT

The main result of this project is that suspended transport and high deposition rates of sand are not necessary to form massive units.  Thus, massive units can be the results of relatively frequent and strong events and not only of extreme  events.  In addition, the experiments demonstrated that when strong currents are present, sediment waves can still be responsible for a significant part of the flow resistances and thus should be accounted for in the calculation of the flood stage.

 

BROADER IMPACTS

 

The results of this study can be directly applied to

1)    Interpret modern and ancient coastal storms and turbidity current deposits; and

2)    Estimate flow depths during floods in relatively small sand bed rivers.

 

The identification of the flow and the sediment transport characteristics in the presence of intense currents can help coastal managers, civil and deep-water engineers in the design and analysis of different types of structures and infrastructures.

 

Four graduate students, six undergraduate students and three high school students participated in the performance of the research activities.  Five female students and two African American students participated in this project.  Six students attended national and international research meetings and workshops.  Two PhD dissertations were completed during the duration of the project. 

 

The project gave the PI and her research group the opportunity to improve the facilities of the Hydraulics Laboratory and to interact with an interdisciplinary and international group of researchers with expertise in stratigraphy, granular physics and sediment transport modeling.

 

Project results have been made available to the public in collaboration with the NSF funded Sediment Experimentalists Network, have been presented as invited talks at international meetings and are summarized in research papers in review or in preparation for submission to peer reviewed journals.
